Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.
speaker: Neil

text: And I'm Sam.
Sam, what blood type are you?
Ah, you mean the different groups used to classify humans by blood?
speaker: Neil

text: Types A, B, A, B and O.
I think I'm type O.
How about you, Neil?
Well, it may sound strange but actually I don’t know.
speaker: Neil

text: Hmm, yeah, lots of Westerners don't know their blood type.
But in parts of Asia, blood groups are a topic of daily conversation.
People select romantic partners based on blood type
and different blood groups are associated with different personalities.
In this programme we’ll be finding out all about blood –
speaker: Neil

text: why humans have different blood types,
and whether blood is something more than just a way of pumping oxygen around your body.
And of course, we'll be learning some new vocabulary as well.
Now, Neil, I have an interesting fact for you.
Did you know that many Japanese pop stars' websites
will feature their blood type alongside information like their age and hobbies?
I didn't say them, but Japanese culture is certainly interested in blood.
There's even a word, brujara, meaning blood harassment,
which is used to describe hostility towards people
speaker: Neil

text: from a certain blood group considered to be selfish.
But which group?
That's my quiz question for today.
Which blood types may fall victim to brujara?
Is it A, blood type A, B, blood type B,
or C, blood type O?
speaker: Neil

text: I’ll say a) blood type A.
speaker: Sam

text: OK, Sam, we'll find out the answer later.
Now, as we've heard, blood is a big deal in Japan.
Mane Chesterton from BBC World Service Programme,
Crowd Science, travel to Tokyo,
where she asked Japanese translators,
Chia Kobayashi, to explain more.
For blood type A, generally it is thought they are perfectionists,
speaker: perfectionists

text: more detailed-oriented, pretty much a good-at-precise type of job.
And that makes them good at helping others,
and good at teamwork, and respect rules and customs.
That's a typical blood type.
40% of Japan's population are sensitive anxious type A's.
30% are curious and stubborn, generous type O's,
10% are creative A, B's,
but woe-betied the 20% type B,
because they have a far less desirable personality, apparently.
According to Japanese tradition,
speaker: perfectionists

text: blood type A's are perfectionists,
people who want everything to be perfect
speaker: Neil

text: and demand the highest standards possible.
This contrasts with type O's who are considered to be stubborn,
people who are determined to do what they want
and refuse to change their mind.
But it’s unfortunate blood type Bs
speaker: Woe betide

text: who have the least desirable personality,
selfish and independent.
Woe-betied the type B's
remarks the presenter, Manny Chesterton.
An informal British expression
said when they will be trouble ahead for someone.
In this case, poor type B's.
But apart from customs and traditions,
is there actually any science behind these beliefs?
Well, not according to Dr Emma Pomoraya
Cambridge University’s archaeology department
speaker: Sam

text: She thinks that, like horoscopes,
there's no scientific basis for a connection
between blood types and personalities.
Which makes me wonder what exactly blood types are.
Blood types are kinds of stickers
speaker: immune system

text: or chemical markers which support our immune system.
The organs, cells and processes
which protect the human body from infection and illness.
Those chemical markers can identify foreign bodies
like pathogens,
small organisms such as a virus or bacteria
that can cause disease.
The variety of blood types seems to be a result
of different bodily responses
to different disease-causing pathogens.
Which explains why blood of the same type
speaker: blood transfusions

text: is needed in blood transfusions.
Medical procedures in which blood is taken from one person
and put into another person's body.
Often after an accident or during an operation.
And explains the high demand for type O blood,
which can be given to anyone.
Ah, generous typos.
Like me, I always knew I was special.
speaker: Sam

text: And curious and stubborn, wasn't that the type O personality?
Oh yes.
Today's quiz question was about blood type personalities.
I asked you which undesirable blood type
is considered selfish in Japan.
And I said, A, blood type A.
But as we've heard, it's actually B, blood type B.
Never mind.
I'll settle for being curious, stubborn and generous.
In today's program, we've been talking all about blood types
and personalities in Japan.
Blood type A people are thought of as perfectionists,
people who want everything to be perfect.
Unlike type Os who are considered stubborn –
speaker: stubborn

text: determined to get their own way and unwilling to change.
And woe be tied, selfish type B's.
An informal expression said,
when they will be trouble for someone,

Scientifically speaking, blood types help support our immune system
